Title: An open ball is an open set
Content: Prove that for any $x_0 \in X$ and any $r>0$, the open ball $B_r(x_o)$ is open. My attempt: Let $y\in B_r(x_0)$. By definition, $d(y,x_0)<r$. I want to show there exists an $r_1\in\mathbb{R^+}$ s.t. $B_{r_{1}}(y)\subseteq B_r(x_0)$. Let $a\in B_{r_{1}}(y)$. Then, $d(a,y)<r_1$. For $a\in B_{r}(x_0)$, $d(a,x_0)<r$. I want to show $d(a,y)<r_1$ implies $d(a,x_0)<r$. By triangle inequality, $d(a,y)\leq d(a,x_0) + d(y,x_0) \rightarrow$  $d(a,y)<r_1\leq d(a,x_0)+d(y,x_0)<2r...$ I'm a little stuck after this point.
AcceptedAnswer:
You need to specify $r_1$ . For $y\in  B_r(x_0)$ , let $r_1=r-d(y,x_0)$ . Then if $x\in B_{r_1}(y)$ $$
d(x,x_0)\le d(x,y)+d(y,x_0)< r_1+ d(y,x_0)=r.
$$ So $ B_{r_1}(y)\subseteq B_r(x_0)$ . This shows that $B_r(x_0)$ is open. $\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad$
